And the knowledge of the measures of this art is a testimony to the measures of diseases: for then you will find by yourself what is suitable for it from the instruments for every illness.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I affirm to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you should place as examples of those on which you will operate, and the test by which you will verify others.
Forma Serrae.	The Form of Serrae.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The Form of Another Serrae.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Form of Another Serrae.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Form of Another Serrae.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the Serra is depicted, but it is misplaced.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let the upper arc be made of iron, its sharpness from the iron: and the handle thereof of boxwood, and let it be pyramidal and misplaced.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The Form of the Joints of the Razor.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this Razor be according to the form of the head of a stellar hammer: and its points be according to the form of the points of elischetfegi.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not fit unless heads of sutures are rubbed with it when they are corrupted, or a wide and large mouth.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Forma maioris Rasorii.
Forma medii Rasorii.	Forma mediae Rasorii.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Forma Rasorii lati.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Forma Rasorii in quo est concavitas.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Forma Rasorii alterius curvatae extremiatis.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis teneae.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Forma Rasorii cum qua inciduntur ossa.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Forma etiam Rasorii magni.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a Radius, and the extremity is like a Saw: exhibited in many places for the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Forma Rasorii quod convenit ad rationem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	Extremitas eius triangulata, acuarum est extremitatum.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all which we have said be made from Rasorii, and Incisoriis, and Serris.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	¶ De incisione extremitatum, et serratura ossium.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter VIII.ToShorter
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrefy, either from an external cause or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated that corruption with medicinal cure, and the cure does not prove effective: and you see the corruption attack the limb, which is not stayed by anything, then it must be that you cut out that limb until where the corruption follows, so that the sick person may escape death through that or because the evil is greater than the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign that this occurs is when the limb darkens until it rots: which fire has burned or decayed after discoloration: until that corruption is cut away to where the rot follows, and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, when you make the incision for it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the strike of certain venomous creatures: such as the marine scorpion, the viper, and the rattle snake, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or strike is in the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption to spread to the remainder of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if this happens in the hand, then cut it off from the root of the finger, and do not leave space for the corruption to spread until it reaches the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades to that extent, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	And if the corruption penetrates and you see it about the elbow: then death of the patient is near.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And administer in addition to that from the cure, is the quantity virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do for the foot, when corruption invades the digit, then cut it at one node: and if it reaches the sole of the foot, then cut the foot entirely.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it has ascended to the knee, then cut the thigh at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no remedy except dismissal and leaving the sick person to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the method of cutting the limb, or sawing it, is to tighten the ligament below the part you wish to cut, and tighten another ligament above the site.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And the attendant stretch one ligament downward: and stretch another ligament upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with Spatulum wide until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it or saw it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it must be that you place a linen cloth from all sides, and the saw does not touch the healthy site: and happen to the sick person an additional injury and a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, an internal flow of blood occurs while working, then cauterize the site quickly: or place some blood-letting powders over it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with an appropriate ligament, and care for it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happens to a man in his foot, this being the same as what I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which is because it happens in his foot as blackening, resembling the burning by fire: and that corruption first occurs on his toe until it began to affect the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore, the man treated himself, after he saw the corruption occur on his limb with the pain he discovered from its blackening: and it affected him at the joint, and he was cured.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred on his index finger.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	Therefore, he came to me, and I tried to recover that flux by what I applied to his hand from medicines after cleansing his body: but the flux did not subside, and it began to affect another finger: until the corruption affected his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	Therefore, he called for me to examine his hand: and I did not want that, hoping for a recovery from the flux: and I even feared death for him at the incision on his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's strength was above his misfortune.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	Therefore, since he despaired of me, he returned to his native land: and he came back to me quickly because of this, and the entire hand was affected: and he was cured.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have included this narrative only as an aid in understanding what falls under the genus of this illness: and as a demonstration to show how it should be handled.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the care of Sinus, and the quality of medicated enemas.
Caput XC.	Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess occurs in certain fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until a collection of sanious matter is formed: then it is broken or perforated, and what is within it exudes from it, leaving a void as if it were a vessel: and the skin above it is like a thin cloth: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, nor impresses upon bone, nor nerve, nor ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: and is not named a Fistula: yet if the space is prolonged until corruption impresses upon one of these members, then it is called a Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is to cut that skin completely away as if it were rolled off: and especially when it is thin like a cloth: and you are confident that it does not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If, however, you suspect that the skin will adhere and does not result in that ultimate corruption: and if there is thickness in the skin from flesh, then treat it with a medicated enema, and consider it as for a Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor: then prepare the medicated enema with Egyptian medicine, which consists of vinegar, oil, and ziniar, taking equal parts, and mix them in a vessel: and boil them over fire until the medicine turns red: and thicken it to the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take what you need from it: and dissolve it with water and honey, and use it to treat the Sinus with an enema: and plug its opening, and let the medicine remain in it for a duration of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: let it remain for days until the sinus is purified and the odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when it is irrigated with ash water, when this medicine is not at hand: and you should take ashes of vine branches or ashes from holm oaks, and pour water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then apply it and irrigate with it until you are confident that the sinus is now cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine nor ash water, then irrigate it with water and honey, to which some crushed zinc has been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or irrigate it with a mixture of honey and wine, for honey has the property to purify and cleanse, while wine helps adhere to the sinus, especially when the wine contains excess astringency and dryness.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you do this several times and are confident that the sinus corruption is removed, then irrigate it with something that causes flesh to regenerate in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And take from the dyafinicon plaster: dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine. Or irrigate it with certain medicines and other ointments whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the sinus opening is narrow, into which the irrigation tube will not fit: then enlarge it slightly with a ironawl. Or place a wick wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basilicon ointment in it until it expands.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly, if the opening is even wide, then suture its edges together: and allow only the amount to enter that can be irrigated without additional material.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly, if the opening from which the pus flows is elevated, then dry it out in a lower place that is within it, so that the pus may flow downward; for when pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated therein.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	And if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus below it as you wish: then try to prepare the flesh with a preparation by which the pus may flow from it easily according to its preparation.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to prevent anything from being retained by the pus altogether: and take consolidating medicines which are applied over the mark, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And apply them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it may cover the entire sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps directly into the opening of the sinus to make a hole, somewhat larger than the opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then apply another cloth with a gentle ointment on it, according to the size of the hole: and place it far from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of the pus may be eased: and do not remove the large cloth unless after several days one by one.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	That which is over the opening of the sinus, you should remove every hour so that what aggregates there from the pus may exit: and by this you will know whether what flows from it is much or little, whether it is digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this, again consider the location of the sinus itself, whether the lord thereof feels pain therein, or there is no pain, and whether there is an abscess therein, or there is not an abscess.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your medical treatment is thus extended, and you see the matter which comes out above the sinus orifice, then know that the sinus now adheres, or approaches adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then replace another pad, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however the subtle poison comes out of the sinus after a long interval, then do not despair of adhesion, for its cure is approaching, since there are men who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and among them are those who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however the foul pus comes out of the sinus after many days, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its course is prolonged: then add to the drying of the medicines, but let the doctors do it so that they are medicines in substance moist and in virtue dry: as with dyafinicon ointment when additional spina sindonis is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the very latest stage of its cure, take the dyafinicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, and sprinkle it over old wine that is equal in substance to it.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then prepare it with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now it performs a similar action when you do not have the dyafinicon ointment at hand, use honey until it thickens and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense: dry the whole, and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then draw a line over the cloth, and bind it above the sinew: and with the thread soaked in honey until it is saturated: and dust the surface with the powder, and place the cloth over it, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And from time to time it is administered with long aristolochia, and the roots of celestial lily, and lily: and herb flour, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use them simple or combined, wash them, and sieve them: and dust the honey as I have told you, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinew prolongs and is not cured by this treatment: then know that there is deep corruption within it. It may have already made an impression in the bones, or in other hard parts, or in the ligaments. Then treat it with the cure for fistulas, as previously stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Regarding the care of fistulas, nail erosion, and incision of the finger, and excision.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XCII.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A panaritm is an abscess that arises under the thumb nail, or the foot nail: and perhaps it arises in other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the condition prolongs, and is neglected by its caretaker, and becomes an abscess with a hot abscess: or it corrupts, and emits pus until it eats into the nail root: and perhaps it corrupts the whole nail, and perhaps corruption reaches the bone until there is a foul odor: and the end of the finger swells, and its color darkens.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you cure it, using what we said in division and the treatment is not sufficient: then you must incise with a knife all the excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cautery is very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the mouth is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the additional nails are already pressing the flesh towards the interior and begin to prick it and hurt it: then you should place Subtile Radium at an angle under the nail that pricks the flesh, and drive it upwards. Cut the flesh with facility, and place over what remains of the flesh from the burning and corrosive medicines until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If the corruption, however, already encroaches on the mouth, then you must cut out that part of the mouth and remove it: for it is never cured while a corrupted mouth remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corruption advancing to the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to the previous mention of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If there is, however, nail friction or impact, and severe pain occurs in it, then you should bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp transverse section of Spathamille from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And beware that the section does not reach the flesh beneath the nail, for you will cause severe pain to the patient and it will be a cause of additional flesh growth in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with what alleviates pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	But the additional digit that is born in some men's hands, perhaps it is wholly fleshy: and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail on it: and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its birthplace is in some knuckles.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore, the one that is born at the knuckles of the digit does not move: and the one that is born at the joint of the digit perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, the one that is fleshy among them, his section is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	What you should do is to cut it at its root with Spatuli lato.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	Therefore, the treatment for that which is born at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, do not cut it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one which is born at the digit at the last knuckle, then you should cut the flesh of it with a round incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then cut the bone with one of those bone-cutting saws that fits it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Consolidation which happens to digits next to each other occurs often either from the person's birth (i.e., it is born with him), or from the healing of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar causes.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, you should cut away that consolidation until the digits return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place among them licorice or cloths soaked in rose oil so that they do not heal quickly, and separate them from each other: or place among them a thin sheet of lead until the area hardens as required.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly, if consolidation occurs in some fingers with the palm, then dry that consolidation according to how it is prepared and fits the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	¶ Incision for Vitiatio.
Caput XCII.	Head XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Uites are veins wrapped up, thick, full of excessive melancholic fluid which affect many parts of the body: and they discharge most frequently in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk much, labor, or carry things.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, you should administer the excision of the body from black bile occasionally with a strong excision.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then phlebotomize the patient and let the basilic vein flow.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these with a steel instrument is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Their vein is to be ligated, and black bile should be drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is to elevate the vein and draw out all of it.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of this should be done according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Anoint the leg first with warm water abundantly, until the thick, foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tie the leg of the patient from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the knee with a ligature.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then sever the vein in one, or two, or three broad sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw off the blood in your hand from the lower part of the leg to the top, and from the upper part it is necessary to incise the phlebotome for the sick first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then sever the nail with its base: continue until a quantity of blood sufficient and as tolerated by the patient emerges.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then ligate it: and instruct him to abstain from foods producing black bile: and repeat the evacuation and phlebotomy when the veins are full, and this is harmful to the sick.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of it is to be done in this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Shave the leg of the patient if there are many hairs.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse it in a bath: or apply warm embrocation with water to the leg until it reddens and the veins swell: or perform vigorous exercise if a bath is not available until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the length of the vein section: or at its end near the knee, or at the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with forceps, and scrape the vein from all sides until it appears to your senses: and at its appearance, you will see it reddening towards blackness.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it therefore flows out of the skin, you will see it white as if it were a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce the Radium beneath it until when it is elevated and comes out of the skin: suspend it with a blind hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry the other section near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then elevate it with the Radium as you did, and suspend it with another blind hook as you did first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry the other section, or multiple sections if needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate it, and cut the last section near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the section that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you extract it from the section that is above, or all higher sections, until it comes out completely: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not comply with your extraction and elevation, then introduce a needle with a strong doubled thread, and ligate it, and extract it. Or introduce the Radium beneath it, and rotate your hand in all directions until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And be careful, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to elevate it greatly, and it enters the surrounding tissues causing harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have extracted it completely, then place over the wound a piece of wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil, and care for it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the Vine is contracted, having a tortuosity with a卷缩 towards parts, and is not as we said according to rectitude: then you must find over it for all parts of its tortuosity, and places of its卷缩.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with forceps until you lift it entirely: and beware at your cut above it not to pierce a vein or wound: for it will be difficult for you to lift or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	Forma Incidendi qua sanatur Vitis.
Forma Vncini caeci.	Forma Vini caeci.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have the same suppleness as other vines, nor is it acute at its extremity, so as not to wound a vein: and it is of great flexibility, being gentle: for if it were subtle, it would wound the vein with its subtlety: rather, its excess in thickness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	Of the Extraction of the Crural Vein.
Caput XCIII.	Head IXIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm lands, such as Alizegi, and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, warm, tender lands, that is, in which no herbs nor trees are born.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from putrefaction that occurs under the skin, just as snakes and ascariasis worms occur within the body, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the onset of this vein's event is that a violent inflammation occurs in the thigh.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the area is blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the Vein begins to emerge from that blistered area, as if it were the root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore the extremity of it becomes apparent, then you should wrap a fragment of lead, whose weight is one third of a drachm, up to two drachms and the node itself, around it; and let the lead hang from the thigh.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore something emerges from it to the exterior, wrap that in lead, and mark it with the node.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it extends greatly, then cut a portion of it, and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it to its root until it has emerged entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh, causing an abscess, putrefaction, and a malignant ulcer to occur.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore, it should be gently handled and drawn out gradually until it emerges from its last portion, and nothing of it remains in the body: in some people, this vein emerges to a length of five handbreadths and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And it has now arrived at me, for it emerged from the man to twenty handbreadths.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If however it occurs to you during your hour of medication: then insert a needle into its aperture, and perforate it with a long aperture, together with the body, until all that is in it from the matter is evacuated: and administer putrefaction to the place for several days with medicinal treatments.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then concern itself with the treatment of abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle or in the foot itself: and it has many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, treat it as we said in the division, and with what was previously mentioned.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	¶ Concerning the section on worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bovine Illness.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCIV.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This illness is called Bovine Illness in certain lands among us: for it often happens in cows, and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it travels throughout the body, ascending and descending: and its presence is felt through the movement from limb to limb until it breaks through a spot in the skin and emerges.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just as worms and snakes, that is, roundworms and ascarids, occur in the stomach.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared because of its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when it travels through the body and rises to the head, and reaches a certain place, then perhaps it opens up there, emerges, and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When therefore you wish to treat it and extract it, then this can be done only through the movement of the worm and its appearance to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must tie what is above him and what is below him with a strong constriction ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry above it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it is deep in the flesh and you do not find it, then place above that place a cautery with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And that which is greater than what is feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then tie below it the eyebrow with a good constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry above it, and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient should use for his purification medicines that dissolve putrid and bad fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	¶ Concerning the incision for the illness Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This illness is called Nakir in our land: it is a pain that occurs in certain limbs and then changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I have indeed seen it myself, as I am narrating to you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some vineyards.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she showed her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the brachium.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for one hour, I saw one inflation move with speed, like a worm, ascending to his shoulder faster than can be: as is the case with live silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore, the pain recessed from that place and fixed itself in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for one hour, and it moved into the remainder of the body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then it told me that it was rotating throughout its entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I therefore marveled at the speed of its permutation from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I, before that, had not seen this illness move in my eyes in such a manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who find the pain move from member to member: and I did not see it with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that to be the case except because the woman was among those who are from the dry body, where veins have been detected: hence this airiness is perceived to have moved.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have humid bodies, where the veins are hidden.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to effect its cure, and the patient feels that pain: then if it is apparent to your eye, as we have said, then bind above it and below it quickly, and draw off that constricted airiness above it, until the airiness exits: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then cure it with the excision of the body, and with that which expels wind, and fumigate it with foul pills, and pills of serpentaria, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	¶ Of the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Head XXCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows vary according to their kinds and according to the places at which they strike the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	The diversity of these arrows is as follows: for some have large and small points, and others are concave and deaf.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And some have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some have barbs.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those that fall upon the limbs vary according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For the limbs are either from principal concave parts, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar organs.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	For when it falls into any of these limbs, and you see signs of death, which I will narrate to you later, then it is necessary to perform the proper extraction from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when you do not see these evil signs, and the arrow is not embedded deep in the limb, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when a dart falls into the brain and penetrates the nose and exits through what is above the brain, it results in: since these are caused by intense heat, scotoma, vertigo, redness of the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasm, confusion of understanding, and vomiting of choler.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood emerges from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And from the place of the wound emerges a white moisture resembling pus.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And what resembles the moisture of flesh exits from it.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore you see these signs, then abstain from treatment, and extract the dart if it does not exit.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the dart when it falls into the heart are: for it is close to the left breast, and one feels as if it were fixed in a hard substance, not in a void.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the dart is similar to the pulse: and black blood flows from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows that cold in the extremities, cold sweat, and syncope.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore, know that death descends without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of the dart when it wounds the lung is the exit of foamy blood from the wound: and the vessels that follow the neck become inflamed, and the color of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he exhales a great, high spirit: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	And if the arrow falls on the veil, which is in the chest: then it is near the small ribs: and there is a great panting with a vehement pain, with a sigh: and all the members of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow falls on the stomach, then perhaps something undigested from the wound will be discharged.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow falls on the Belly and is fixed therein: something of feces emerges from the wound, or that which is intestinal and already disrupted.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore, there is no hope in curing him, nor in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	And if the arrow falls on the Bladder and urine emerges: and something proceeds from it to the external parts, and the pain is more severe upon the sick man: then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	And the other limbs, such as the face, neck, throat, spout (possibly a surgical tool), assistant bone, vertebrae of the back, fork骨（可能是手术工具），助骨，脊椎，叉骨，和类似部位，根据不同的位置治疗：当箭没有找到动脉或神经，并且不是毒 arrow。
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen about these arrows, so that you may understand it for your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Because an arrow fell on the lacrimal apparatus of one man, at the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore, I extracted it from the other side, beneath the fatty tissue of his ear: and he was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which fell into the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not find it except for its small end, with which it adheres to its wood: and the arrow was large among arrows of the Turcos, having soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	Therefore, the Jew was cured, and no evil happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of the Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arabic arrow, and it has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I cut it above the arrow between two guides: and it was already submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I extracted it carefully until I removed it: and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another arrow from a man which had fallen into his abdomen: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed, and nothing changed in his condition, I cut above the arrow: and I extracted it with care: and he was cured, and no evil happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man from whose back an arrow had fallen, and the wound healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years had passed, an arrow emerged from the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman from whose abdomen an arrow had fallen, and the wound healed over it, and the arrow remained within her: and nothing changed in her condition, and the woman found no harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whose face an arrow had fallen: and the wound had become consolidated, and remained, not finding him in great pain: and similar to these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted the arrow from one of the king's men, which had fallen into the middle of his nose, and had already slightly declined to the right side: and the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was therefore called to cure him after the arrow fell until three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the arrow wound very deep.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I examined it with a fine probe and did not sense the arrow: and he himself found a puncture and pain on the side of his ear from the right.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that this puncture was at the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I applied a plaster to the area with a plaster that had drawing and dissipating properties, and I trusted that the place would suppurate and show me a sign of the arrow, so that I could cut above it: and nothing happened in the place that would indicate that the arrow had reached it.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I applied a plaster to him daily for many days: and nothing happened, and the wound consolidated in the meantime: and he remained weak from the extraction for a space of days until he felt the arrow within his nose on a certain day.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about it.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I applied a sharp and corrosive medicine to the wound for many days until it opened up: and when I probed it again, I felt the fine tip of the arrow adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the incision of the wound by means of that sharp medicine until we visibly saw the extremity of the arrow, and it passed with it a space of time about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then, after the wound had been enlarged, and it was possible for me to introduce forceps into it and move it, and it did not yield to extraction: then I ceased not to refine and devise methods for it until one day with properly made forceps, as their form is described at the end of this chapter, I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians indeed judge that the cartilage of the nose does not restore itself.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Then I restored it, and the wound healed firmly, and the sick man was completely cured: nor did anything harm him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you may establish a rule and definition for what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not included in the narration: nor does the book encompass it, and a skilled artisan compares it with a little more and a little less: and with that which is present, to that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument at the descent of matters foreign to this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say that arrows do not exit from the parts where they are fixed unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or through attraction from the place whence it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite side.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place: and is drawn out, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	And if it does not respond to the exit at the time it falls: then it is necessary to let it alone for a few days until the flesh around it putrifies. And the drawing out and its exit should be alleviated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly, if it is embedded in bone, and does not respond to your efforts for exit, then let it alone for a few days: and repeat it with drawing and motion every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	And if it does not respond to your efforts for exit after days, then it is necessary to perforate around the arrow in the bone from every side with a sharp probe until the arrows swell.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If the arrow is fixed in the head bone, and has already penetrated into one ventricle of the brain, and apparent are certain of those accidents which I said: then abstain from drawing the arrow, and let it alone until its condition equalsize after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the brain, then death is not prolonged to him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, but only in the bone of the body and does not penetrate all the way to the brain: and the patient remains ill for a few days, and nothing of those accidents happens to him: then proceed with the drawing out of the arrow and its extraction.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If it is fixed very much and does not obey to attraction as I have told you: then apply turpentine around the arrowhead, as I have said to you; then care for the place until it is healed.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow has already hidden in the body and is concealed from sensation: then seek it out and probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with instruments that are suitable for its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot draw it out due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow deep within: and there is no hole, nor nerve, nor vein there: then cut above it until the wound expands, making it possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are ears through which it is held, then free the flesh fixed therein from every side with all skill you can, and use other methods. If this cannot be done by freeing the flesh through a puncture in the ear, then distort the ear until the arrow emerges.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you perform the extraction of the arrow in any place, then use the distortion of your hand with forceps on all parts until you make it emerge: and with utmost subtlety, so that the arrow is not broken, and the attraction and extraction become difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot extract it in one attempt, then leave it for a few days until the tissue around it becomes putrefied.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the procedure: for it will become easier with the putrefaction. If however, it causes contrary effects such as a blood flow, then apply what we have said in the cure chapter of its section, and guard your strength from cutting the vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the skill in every way that is possible to thee for the discharge of the Arrow: and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or tardiness, and firmness, as I have told thee.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And thou shalt do it when drawing the Arrow, so that it be weak according to the figure, according to which it was at the time of the fall of the Arrow.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more advantageous.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If, however, this is not possible for thee, then administer what is possible for thee from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The Arrow which comes out from the opposite part of the other, or has proceeded from it to the exterior: causes a gibbosity at the end of the Arrow by a sense from the neighboring skin above, and thou seest it projecting. Therefore cut above it, and let the cut be according to the quantity that the forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for it becomes easy to extract.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If, however, it is retained in the bone, then twist thy hand according to the roundness until the Arrow presses into the bone and enlarges itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not, let it alone for a few days, then repeat it until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the wood of the Arrow is in it, then push it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood has fallen off, and thou wishest to administer a push: then introduce into it a concave instrument, so that its concavity enters the fletching of the Arrow: then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then drive it with an instrument entering into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be extracted through this.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then one must extract all the flesh in which the poison is located: if it is possible for you to do so.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what is suitable for it.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is lodged in the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or in the side: and it is near because you can feel it when you probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut and be careful of cutting a vein or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then dress the wound if you see it, and treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the extremities be similar to the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp over the arrow, they do not let go of it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many species of forceps are made, large and small, and those of medium size, according to the size and thickness of the arrow, and the width and tension of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of the driving instrument for concave arrows.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the driving instrument for blunt arrows.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the blunt arrow's extremity, like a radius, so that it can enter into the concave arrow and be driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This extremity of the thrusting concave is concave like a bird's feather: so that the entrance of the arrow into it may be lightened and its impulse.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	¶ On Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XC VII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	Veins to be phlebotomized, of which custom runs in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From which in the head are sixteen: two Pulsatiles veins, which are behind the ears and called the two Herbae: and two Arteries, which appear in the two temples: and two veins which are in the two lacrimal glands of both eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and one vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and one vein which is at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins to be phlebotomized in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is Cephalica, and it is from the side of the tree (or wood): and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of the basilicon branch and the cephalic branch: and the common people name it the body vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the basilicon, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also named titillaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people name it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the brachial vein, and it is placed above the basilicon: and that is the one in which phlebotomy is performed, and that is the one which appears above the thumb when examined clearly.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Saluatella: and it is a vein which is between the annular and the smallest: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the thigh and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the vein which is below the curvature of the thumb from the Sylvian side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its location is near the heel from the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the vein Nesse: and its location is near the heel from the Sylvian side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the thigh there are three other veins similar to them.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	¶ On phlebotomy of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Phlebotomy of the two veins behind the ears is helpful for old catarrhs, hemigraine, sahafati, and old maladies of the head.
